description:
Candidatus Amarolinea aalborgensis is a recently discovered and proposed bacterial species that belongs to the phylum Chloroflexi. It was first identified and characterized from a wastewater treatment plant in Aalborg, Denmark, which is the origin of its species name "aalborgensis".

Candidatus Amarolinea aalborgensis is an obligate anaerobic, filamentous bacterium that is believed to play a role in the process of biological phosphorus removal in wastewater treatment systems. It is capable of accumulating large amounts of polyphosphate granules within its cells, which is a characteristic feature of many bacteria involved in enhanced biological phosphorus removal.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Candidatus Amarolinea aalborgensis is closely related to other uncultured Chloroflexi bacteria commonly found in various wastewater treatment environments. However, it has not yet been successfully isolated and cultured in the laboratory, hence its designation as a "Candidatus" species.

Further research is needed to better understand the physiology, ecology, and specific role of Candidatus Amarolinea aalborgensis in wastewater treatment processes, as well as its potential applications in biotechnology and environmental engineering.
